路透社路透社全文RSS。获取更多全文RSS：https://feedx.net http://reuters.com Futures drop as rate worries keep Treasury yields near recent peakshttps://reuters.com/article/usa-stocks/futures-drop-as-rate-worries-keep-treasury-yields-near-recent-peaks-idUSKBN30W0MH
;;2023-09-26T11:33:38Z;
;;
;;2023 年 7 月 26 日，交易员在美国纽约市纽约证券交易所 (NYSE) 的交易大厅工作。 REUTERS/ Brendan McDermid/档案照片;
;

;美国股指期货周二下跌，因为投资者继续努力应对美联储长期限制性货币政策的前景及其对经济的后续影响。< /p>;

;增加投资者焦虑的是;美国政府将于周日部分关闭;，根据评级机构穆迪的说法，这可能是“;信用负面;”。

;

;包括苹果在内的大型成长股;(AAPL.O);，微软 ;(MSFT.O);，元平台;(META.O)< /a>; 和特斯拉 ;(TSLA.O); 下跌 0.5% 至 1.3%在盘前交易中。

;

;Amazon.com 股票;(AMZN.O)<在;提振华尔街;之后，/a>; 也下跌了 0.5%周一，其计划投资备受瞩目的初创公司 Anthropic。

;

;美国东部时间上午 7:12，道指 e-minis 下跌 157 点，即 0.46%，标准普尔 500 e-minis 下跌 23.75下跌 0.54%，纳斯达克 100 e-minis 下跌 92.25 点，即 0.62%。

;

;美国三大股指今年将首次录得季度下跌，进入去年9 月交易日。

;

;在美联储对长期利率前景采取强硬立场（其他主要央行也预测了这一立场）后，基准的两年期和十年期国债收益率已升至多年高点，给股市带来压力.

;

;“人们越来越感到沮丧，因为利率不会很快下降，而且利率将在很长一段时间内保持在限制性范围内，从而阻碍增长并使经济环境变得更加困难。 Equiti Capital 首席宏观经济学家斯图尔特·科尔 (Stuart Cole) 表示，11 月和 12 月交易员对基准利率保持不变的押注分别接近 80% 和 59%。 CME 的 FedWatch 工具。与此同时，最早在 3 月份就已经考虑降息 25 个基点，并在 6 月和 7 月增至 33% 以上。

;

;投资者将密切关注 9 月和 9 月的消费者信心指数。八月份新屋销售报告将于开盘后发布。

;

;本周数据包括耐用品、八月份个人消费支出价格指数、第二季度国内生产总值等主席杰罗姆·鲍威尔等美联储政策制定者的言论将受到监控。

;

;明尼阿波利斯联储主席;尼尔·卡什卡里;周一指出，鉴于经济出人意料的弹性，有必要提高借贷成本以抑制通胀，而芝加哥联储主席;Austan Goolsbee;在接受CNBC采访时表示，通胀率高于2%的目标仍然是比经济放缓范围更大的风险

;

;与此同时，;高盛报告显示，上周对冲基金主要增加了对美股的看空押注，客户大多增加空头头寸并摆脱多头头寸。非必需消费品、工业和金融股的净卖出量最大。

;

;中国公司京东、拼多多在美国上市的股票;(PDD.O); 和小鹏汽车因经济担忧和地缘政治紧张局势而下跌 1.3% 至 3%。

;

;DraftKings ;(DKNG.O); 在摩根大通将在线体育和游戏公司的股票评级上调至“增持”后，该公司股价上涨 3% ”来自“中性”。

; Tue, 26 Sep 2023 19:55:04 +0800 US yields at 2007 levels crimp stocks, while yen sirens blarehttps://reuters.com/article/global-markets/us-yields-at-2007-levels-crimp-stocks-while-yen-sirens-blare-idUSKBN30W02L
;;2023-09-26T11:17:24Z;
;

;美国国债收益率周二触及 2007-2008 年全球金融危机早期震动以来的最高点，对利率长期维持在高位的担忧扰乱了全球风险资产，并推动美元升至 10 个月高位。

;

;亚洲和欧洲股市基准下跌，美国股市也将效仿，原油价格下跌美联储官员最近发表的言论导致美国收益率曲线看跌陡峭。

;

;600 种欧洲股票的基准 STOXX 指数 ;(.STOXX); 下跌 0.5%，与 MSCI 最广泛的亚太股票指数早些时候的下跌趋势一致 ;(.MIAP00000PUS);。

;

;10年期国债收益率高达4.566%，较16年期国债收益率高债券收益率与价格成反比，当发行人面临风险时，债券收益率就会上升，而本周大量的美国国债拍卖以及对美国政府关门的担忧都进一步加剧了不安情绪。欧元区主权国家认为利率正在增长，并且仍然处于高位，因为中央银行将在更长时间内保持较高的利率。

;

;作为欧元区基准的德国 10 年期政府债券收益率最近几乎没有变化当天的收益率为 2.789%，早盘曾一度触及 12 年高点 2.813%。

;

;意大利基准 10 年期 BTP 债券与更安全的德国国债之间的收益率差距已升至约1.86 个百分点（186 个基点），为 5 月底以来最大涨幅，总理乔治亚·梅洛尼 ;表示;鉴于美国经济令人惊讶的弹性，可能需要进一步加息。

;

;共和党的努力加剧了围绕美国政府债务的紧张情绪- 控制的众议院;本周将推进大幅削减支出;，该法案没有机会成为法律，但可能会在下周日之前引发政府部分关闭。

;

;如果国会无法做到这一点，数十万联邦工作人员可能会被迫休假，公共服务可能会暂停为从 10 月 1 日开始的新财政年度提供资金。

;

;交易员现在将美联储在 1 月份再次加息四分之一个百分点的可能性视为抛硬币，并将可能开始降息的时间推迟到夏季。

;

; p>;

;芝加哥联储主席奥斯坦·古尔斯比;表示;周一，通胀持续高于央行 2% 的目标仍然是比美联储紧缩政策导致经济放缓的风险更大的风险。

;

;欧洲央行和英国央行也在较长时间内宣扬加息。自本月中旬以来的政策会议。

;

;衡量美元兑欧元和日元等六种主要发达市场货币的美元指数上涨 0.2%，至 106.2，为 2022 年 11 月以来的最高水平随着全球最大经济体继续跑赢大盘。

;

;美元兑日元走强尤其让交易者警惕干预措施以支撑日元，尤其是在财务大臣铃木俊一周二表示< a href="/world/asia-pacific/japan-finmin-warns-markets-yen-nears-intervention-danger-zone-2023-09-26/">;没有任何选择。;;

;隔夜美元兑日元汇率维持在 11 个月高点 148.97 日元附近，金融市场将 1 美元兑 150 日元视为红线，将促使日本当局像去年那样采取行动。

;

;金价小幅走低至 1,910.6 美元，延续过去一周 1,947 美元以上的跌势，因美元走强的阴影下，黄金的吸引力减弱。

;

;由于担心燃料需求将下降，原油依然疲软。尽管供应预计将吃紧，但主要央行仍将利率维持在较高水平，从而导致油价下跌。

;

;布伦特原油期货下跌 72 美分，至每桶 92.57 美元，而美国西德克萨斯中质原油期货价格为每桶 69 美分美分下跌至 89.99 美元。

;

;相关图库：

;;
;;2023 年 9 月 11 日，交易员在美国纽约市纽约证券交易所 (NYSE) 的交易大厅工作。REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/file照片;
;;
;;2023 年 4 月 18 日，日本东京一家经纪公司外的电子股票报价板上映出一名男子的倒影。 REUTERS/Issei Kato/档案照片;
;
;

; Tue, 26 Sep 2023 19:25:03 +0800 Sudan“s displaced millions struggle to survive as economy seizes uphttps://reuters.com/article/sudan-politics-displacement/sudans-displaced-millions-struggle-to-survive-as-economy-seizes-up-idUSKBN30W0N2
;;2023-09-26T10:31:00Z;
;;
;;2023 年 9 月 3 日，苏丹恩图曼，人们拿着锅，志愿者分发食物。REUTERS/El Tayeb Siddig/档案照片;
;

;大约两个月后，谢里夫·阿卜杜勒莫奈姆 (Sherif Abdelmoneim) 位于苏丹首都的家周围发生严重冲突，被迫逃离，不断飙升的房租和食品价格迫使这位 36 岁的谢里夫和他的六口之家返回了一座发生战斗的城市。仍然愤怒。

;

;大多数人在军队和准军事快速支援部队（RSF）之间的战争后逃离喀土穆;4月中旬爆发;还没回来。他们面临着营养不良、洪水和蝎子等问题，因为他们依靠施舍和微薄的援助救济生存，收容社区的慷慨也越来越薄弱。

;

;自战斗以来，苏丹 4900 万人口中有超过 525 万人背井离乡。根据联合国的数据，火山爆发了。其中超过 100 万人已越境进入邻国，但超过 410 万人留在苏丹，他们在那里承受着越来越大的财务压力。

;

;“各州（喀土穆以外）很安全，但物价却很昂贵。阿卜杜勒莫奈姆在毗邻喀土穆的恩图曼市接受电话采访时说：“这里的房子很贵，租金也很高，我们不能再这样下去了。” .

;

;冲突导致苏丹停滞的经济陷入瘫痪，许多贸易和运输受阻，;阻碍农业生产;，停止许多工资支付，并对基础设施造成巨大破坏。

;

;该国现在必须利用仅剩的微薄资源来支持国内流离失所者（如果算上因之前的冲突而无家可归的人）已达近 710 万，比世界上任何其他国家都多。

;

;援助人员预计，支付租金或免费住宿的人中会有更多人当他们逃离首都时，随着资金枯竭，他们最终会被安置在集体避难所。

;

;“我们热情好客，但人们处理的事情超出了他们的能力，”卡萨拉的政府官员奥马尔·奥斯曼说。说租金大幅上涨。 “如果战争继续下去，这些人的积蓄很少，因此他们需要庇护所。”

;

;受战争影响较小的地区的收容社区一直在遭受战争的连锁反应。

;

; >;

;在喀土穆以南约 275 公里（170 英里）处的拉巴克，战争爆发前，许多年轻人一直试图在工厂里谋生，或者在首都当临时工。

;

;"对于当地人来说，劳动力市场陷入瘫痪。喀土穆是该国其他地区的引擎。”居民 Fadeel Omer 说。

;

;该市的流离失所者无力承担房租，被安置在墙壁摇摇欲坠的避难所里，他说，蝎子和一些营养不良的儿童每天都在市医院死去。大批人已返回喀土穆。

;

;在喀土穆以北 340 公里的麦洛韦，工薪阶层和农民的收入已经枯竭，当地志愿者正在努力为流离失所者提供基本膳食，其中一些人律师兼当地志愿者 Izdihar Jumaa 说，他们睡在沙发或桌子上。

;

;喀土穆、达尔富尔和科尔多凡这三个受战争影响最严重的地区的基础设施受损可能达 600 亿美元，即 10%。苏丹前财政部长兼经济研究员易卜拉欣·巴达维 (Ibrahim al-Badawi) 表示，它的总价值。他估计今年国内生产总值可能会下降 20%。

;

;“如果战争停止，苏丹将需要 5 至 100 亿美元的紧急经济支持来重振经济，”他在 2019 年接受路透社采访时表示。迪拜。

;

;“战争的持续将导致苏丹经济和国家的毁灭。”

;

;战争爆发以来，许多产品的价格飙升。在红海城市苏丹港（政府官员和援助人员的中心）的黑市上，苏丹镑兑美元汇率从 4 月份的约 560 英镑跌至 900 苏丹镑兑一美元。

;

;A奥马尔·哈利勒 (Omar Khalil) 于 6 月与妻子和三个孩子从恩图曼逃到苏丹港，他说，对许多人来说，居住在国外的苏丹人寄来的汇款是许多人的持续生命线。

;

;“他们是肩负这一重担的人。 ，“ 他说。 “这不可能永远持续下去。”卡里尔和他的妻子都曾是艺术教师，现在在家制作冰淇淋卖给超市。

;

;国际对苏丹的援助资金严重不足，今年所需的 26 亿美元资金还不到 25%据联合国称，已于 8 月中旬收到。援助人员表示，政府的繁文缛节以及首都服务和后勤的崩溃也阻碍了救援行动。

;

;当局对当地志愿者的救援行动感到紧张，并希望将流离失所者安置在营地中挪威难民委员会的威尔·卡特 (Will Carter) 表示，但没有资金来运营所需的规模。

;

;在苏丹各地，一些一直租房的流离失所者被驱逐，尽管大多数人都被驱逐了。他说，仍然住在大家庭或陌生人家里。 “我们将陷入僵局——这些城市里的占屋者将陷入贫困，”他补充道。

; Tue, 26 Sep 2023 18:55:04 +0800 Singapore blows up 100kg World War Two bombhttps://reuters.com/article/singapore-ww2-bomb/singapore-blows-up-100kg-world-war-two-bomb-idUSKBN30W0O1
;;2023-09-26T10:39:55Z;
;

;警方称，新加坡拆弹专家在疏散更多人员后，周二成功处理了一枚 100 公斤的第二次世界大战空投炸弹附近有超过 4,000 人居住。

;

;在新加坡陆军发布的一段视频中，可以看到这枚炸弹在一个建筑工地引爆，并发出巨大的轰鸣声。这被认为是新加坡发现的最大的战时爆炸物之一。

;

;据警方称，上周出土的战争遗迹被认为不安全，因此必须由军方就地处置。< /p>;

;爆炸后，建筑物和道路被认为结构安全，居民被允许回家，警方说。

;

;新加坡当局没有提及炸弹的来源。

;

; >;

;据当地报纸《海峡时报》报道，2016 年发现并处置了另一枚 100 公斤的第二次世界大战炸弹，但当时没有平民撤离的报道。

;

;第二次世界大战期间，新加坡被占领1942 年至 1945 年间由日本人建造。

; Tue, 26 Sep 2023 18:55:04 +0800 Serbs in Kosovo declare mourning for those killed in shootouthttps://reuters.com/article/kosovo-serbia-shooting/serbs-in-kosovo-declare-mourning-for-those-killed-in-shootout-idUSKBN30W0NU
;;2023-09-26T10:45:50Z;
;;
;;2023 年 9 月 26 日，科索沃兹韦坎附近发生枪击事件后，科索沃警察在通往 Banjska 修道院的道路上巡逻。 路透社/Ognen Teofilovski/档案照片;
;

;代表科索沃北部塞族人的主要政党周二宣布为在与科索沃警察枪战中丧生的人哀悼三天，此前科索沃发生了多年来最严重的暴力事件

;

;科索沃当局表示，大约 30 名全副武装的塞族人;周日;，与警察交战，并把自己关进塞尔维亚东正教修道院。在三名袭击者和一名警察被杀后，警方于周日晚些时候重新夺回了修道院。

;

;没有任何组织站出来声称对此次袭击负责或解释枪手的动机。科索沃指责塞尔维亚支持武装武装分子；塞尔维亚称科索沃应为虐待塞族占多数地区的居民负责。

;

;“由于在班尼斯卡发生的悲惨事件中杀害了我们的同胞，因此宣布 9 月 26 日、27 日和 28 日为哀悼日。塞族名单党说：“我们代表塞族名单和科索沃塞尔维亚人民向遇难者家属表示最深切的哀悼。”周二，两名在枪战中被俘的塞族人在全副武装的警察戴着手铐的护送下，在科索沃首都普里什蒂纳出庭参加听证会。法院称，第三名受伤的枪手嫌疑人已在医院接受法官审讯，他被指控参与恐怖袭击，并被还押一个月。

;

;这场枪战引发了新的国际关注人们对科索沃的稳定表示担忧。该国阿尔巴尼亚族占多数，在游击队起义和 1999 年北约干预后，科索沃于 2006 年宣布从塞尔维亚独立。

;

;贝尔格莱德从未承认其前省份的独立。北部约 50,000 名塞族人拒绝普里什蒂纳的统治。

;

;塞尔维亚本身宣布周三为哀悼日，“因为周日在科索沃发生的悲惨事件”，但没有明确支持枪手或他们的不满。

;

;塞尔维亚本身宣布周三为哀悼日，但没有明确支持枪手或他们的不满。塞尔维亚总统亚历山大·武契奇周二在贝尔格莱德会见了美国、欧盟、英国、法国、德国和意大利大使。他说，他已要求国际驻科部队维和部队“而不是（科索沃总理阿尔宾）库尔蒂的警察来处理科索沃北部的所有安全问题”。

;

;周一武装科索沃警察;搜查了巴尼斯卡的房屋;，寻找任何可能袭击的枪手警方还展示了他们称缴获的一系列武器和弹药，其中包括前南斯拉夫军队的突击步枪。 、机枪、狙击步枪、迫击炮、反坦克火箭发射器、手榴弹、地雷和无人机。

;
;

; Tue, 26 Sep 2023 18:55:04 +0800 Russian Black Sea commander shown working after Ukraine said it killed himhttps://reuters.com/article/ukraine-crisis-navy-commander/russian-black-sea-commander-shown-working-after-ukraine-said-it-killed-him-idUSKBN30W0NE
;;2023-09-26T10:49:46Z;
;

;俄罗斯黑海舰队司令、俄罗斯最高级海军军官之一维克托·索科洛夫被拍到参加视频周二的会议上，乌克兰特种部队表示他们已经杀死了他。

;

;在俄罗斯国防部发布的一张照片中，索科洛夫显然正在参加与国防部长谢尔盖·绍伊古等人的视频会议高级海军上将和陆军参谋长。

;

;;乌克兰特种部队周一表示，他们在上周针对俄罗斯黑海舰队位于塞瓦斯托波尔港总部的导弹袭击中杀死了莫斯科驻克里米亚最高海军上将索科洛夫以及其他 33 名军官.

;

;相关图库：

;;< div>;;俄罗斯国防部长谢尔盖·绍伊古在俄罗斯莫斯科主持与武装部队领导层的会议，通过视频链接在屏幕上看到俄罗斯舰队指挥官。图片发布于 2023 年 9 月 26 日。俄罗斯国防部/路透社的讲义;;;
;;俄罗斯黑海舰队司令维克多·索科洛夫中将在塞瓦斯托波尔为部分动员期间征召的预备役军人举行的送别仪式上敬礼，克里米亚，2022 年 9 月 27 日。REUTERS/Alexey Pavlishak/档案照片;
;;
;;这张照片于 2023 年 9 月 26 日发布，俄罗斯国防部长谢尔盖·绍伊古在俄罗斯莫斯科主持与武装部队领导层的会议。国防部/路透社的讲义;
; Tue, 26 Sep 2023 18:55:04 +0800 Kremlin says U.S. Abrams tanks, ATACMS missiles for Ukraine can“t change battlefield situationhttps://reuters.com/article/ukraine-crisis-abrams-russia/kremlin-says-u-s-abrams-tanks-atacms-missiles-for-ukraine-cant-change-battlefield-situation-idUSKBN30W0OZ
;;2023-09-26T10:53:43Z;
;

;克里姆林宫周二表示，美国向乌克兰提供远程 ATACMS 导弹和艾布拉姆斯坦克不会改变局势克里姆林宫发言人德米特里·佩斯科夫在例行新闻发布会上被问及这个问题时表示，俄罗斯武装部队正在不断适应新型武器的使用，莫斯科称之为特种军事行动（

;

;“所有这一切都不能影响SVO的本质及其结果。没有任何灵丹妙药，也没有任何一种武器可以改变战场上的力量平衡， ”他说。

;

;乌克兰总统弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基周二表示，美国制造的艾布拉姆斯坦克有;到达;他的国家。喷气动力坦克是基辅的首要需求，直到华盛顿在一月份最终提供了 30 多辆。

;

;“艾布拉姆斯坦克是严肃的武器，但请记住总统对其他国家制造的其他坦克的评价，”佩斯科夫说，他指的是供应给基辅的其他西方坦克，其中包括德国制造的豹式坦克和英国挑战者式坦克。

;

;“好吧，这些（艾布拉姆斯）也会燃烧，”他说。

;

;基辅还多次要求拜登政府提供陆军战术导弹系统 (ATACMS)，以帮助攻击和破坏俄罗斯占领领土上的补给线、空军基地和铁路网络。

;

;上周五，NBC 新闻援引美国官员的话报道称，乔·拜登总统已;告知;泽连斯基，华盛顿还将向基辅提供 ATACMS 远程导弹。

;

;白宫和五角大楼拒绝对 NBC 的报道发表评论。五角大楼还拒绝透露泽伦斯基上周四在五角大楼举行的会议上是否向他做出了 ATACMS 的任何承诺。

;

;“美国人继续增加……直接参与这场冲突，但是当然每当我们的军队提高对抗这些导弹的技能和技术能力时，”佩斯科夫说。

; Tue, 26 Sep 2023 18:55:04 +0800 Shutdown showdown in US Congress: Time running short to fund governmenthttps://reuters.com/article/usa-shutdown/shutdown-showdown-in-us-congress-time-running-short-to-fund-government-idUSKBN30W0KU
;;2023-09-26T10:01:38Z;
;;
;;美国国会大厦的总体景观，国会将于周二返回国会大厦，在资金耗尽并引发一系列支出法案之前处理一系列支出法案2023 年 9 月 25 日，美国华盛顿，美国政府部分关闭。路透社/乔纳森·恩斯特;
;

;美国众议院和参议院周二计划在一场高风险的支出战中采取截然不同的路径，距离最后期限仅剩五天，这可能会迫使政府大部分部门在十年内第四次关闭。

;

;民主党控制的参议院计划在两党支持下就一项权宜之计的拨款法案进行投票这将使联邦政府在周六午夜（格林威治标准时间周日 0400 点）用完当前资金后继续运转，从而使谈判人员有更多时间就全年支出数字达成一致。

;

;与此同时，共和党众议院议长凯文·麦卡锡 (Kevin McCarthy)旨在阻止自己核心小组中强硬派成员叛乱的特朗普将推进四项全年支出法案，这些法案反映了保守派的优先事项，但没有机会成为法律。

;

;数十万联邦工作人员将休假，并提供;广泛的服务;数据发布;营养效益;，将如果双方未能达成协议，比赛将于周日开始暂停。在华盛顿，国家动物园表示将不得不;减少告别活动在三只大熊猫返回中国之前为它们举办派对;。

;

;国会已经关闭了政府;自 1981 年以来有 14 次;，尽管大多数资金缺口只持续了一两天。虽然具有破坏性，但并未对世界最大经济体产生重大影响。

;

;但是穆迪的;周一警告;，这次政府关门将对美国政府的 AAA 信用评级产生负面影响，因为这将凸显政治极化如何恶化该国的财政状况。< /p>;

;民主党总统乔·拜登和麦卡锡五月份在联邦债务上限僵局结束后同意在开始的财政年度增加 1.59 万亿美元的可自由支配支出，当时他们的目标是避免今年的政府关门。 10 月 1 日。

;

;麦卡锡右翼议员此后拒绝了这一数字，要求削减 1200 亿美元，尽管包括参议院共和党高层在内的党内较为温和的成员表示支持商定的计划。< /p>;

;这仅占美国预算总额的一小部分，本财年美国预算总额将达到 6.4 万亿美元。立法者;不考虑削减;社会保障等受欢迎的福利计划和医疗保险，预计随着人口老龄化，这些项目将急剧增长。

;

;共和党以 221 比 212 的微弱优势控制众议院，几乎没有多余的选票，特别是因为一些共和党强硬派威胁要采取罢免行动如果麦卡锡依靠民主党选票通过立法，他将不再担任领导职务。

;

;;拜登本人;呼吁众议院共和党人尊重麦卡锡的协议。

;

;“就在几个月前，众议院议长和我同意政府支出水平， ”拜登说。 “现在一小群极端的众议院共和党人不想履行这项协议，美国的每个人都可能面临为此付出代价。”

;

;尽管关闭最后期限迫在眉睫，众议院将首先将注意力转向四项全年法案，即使这些法案获得通过，也无法为整个政府提供资金或阻止政府关门。成功并不能保证：共和党强硬派上周阻止了支出法案的行动，一些人表示他们将再次尝试这样做。

;

;如果麦卡锡克服了第一个障碍，辩论可能会花费一周的大部分时间，留下很少的内容是时候在周日之前敲定一项权宜之计的法案了。

;

;强硬派众议院自由核心小组成员、共和党众议员拉尔夫·诺曼周一表示，他“100%”确定国会无法维持该法案政府开放。

;

;麦卡锡说他更加乐观。 “我正在尽一切努力确保这种情况不会发生，”他周一告诉记者。 “我总是喜欢最后一秒的球。”

;

;目前还不清楚这会如何发挥。如果参议院通过一项权宜之计的拨款法案，麦卡锡可能会允许在众议院进行投票，该法案可能会在民主党和更务实的共和党人的支持下获得通过。

;

;但这可能会促使共和党强硬派对他们的威胁采取行动;废黜;麦卡锡，冲入会议厅进一步陷入混乱。

;

;2024 年共和党提名的领跑者、前总统唐纳德·特朗普一直在为政府关门言论欢呼，他在他的 Truth 社交媒体网站上表示，“除非你得到了一切，否则就闭嘴吧”下来！”

; Tue, 26 Sep 2023 18:25:04 +0800 The elusive Fed “soft landing“ nears. Why are Americans so mad about the economy?https://reuters.com/article/usa-economy-inflation/the-elusive-fed-soft-landing-nears-why-are-americans-so-mad-about-the-economy-idUSKBN30W0LL
;;2023-09-26T10:09:36Z;
;

;美联储主席杰罗姆·鲍威尔上周强调，人们“讨厌通货膨胀，讨厌它”，但他留下了另一句话不言而喻的事实是，当物价上涨时，他们还会惩罚负责的政客。

;

;央行寻求物价缓慢上涨和持续经济增长的“软着陆”的可能性似乎越来越大。事实上，美国;可能会达到最佳点; 正如明年 2024 年总统竞选活动将达到高潮。

;

;这是学术研究和高级经济学家认为几乎不可能的良性结果;after inflation hit 40-year highs; in June of 2022. Some warned that millions of workers might need to be rendered jobless to reduce the pace of price increases in a flashback to the central banking experience of the 1970s.

;

;Rather than cheering, though, after years of economic turbulence since the coronavirus pandemic erupted in 2020, Americans grumble, at least if you ask them about the economy.

;

;More than 40% of US voters who backed Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election say they think the economy is worse off than it was then, a ;Reuters/Ipsos poll; published last month found.;

;The front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination, former President Donald Trump, faces a string of criminal indictments related to his attempts to overturn the 2020 election. Still, several ;recent polls; show him tied with Biden in a hypothetical 2024 matchup.

;

;That's because things on the ground don't feel as good as the positive inflation trend would indicate. With fast rising prices and the end of an array of pandemic-era government benefit programs, inflation-adjusted household income fell last year, and the poverty rate increased.

;

;Borrowing costs also have risen sharply in the past 18 months as the Fed ratcheted up interest rates to tame the surge in inflation, adding to consumers' sour mood.

;

;Past presidential elections have often seemed to turn on pocketbook issues. High inflation and a Fed-induced recession hampered President Jimmy Carter's 1980 reelection campaign against Republican candidate Ronald Reagan; President George HW Bush was hobbled by rising unemployment, a spike in prices, and a recession in his 1992 bid for a second term against Democrat Bill Clinton, the race in which a Clinton adviser famously framed campaign strategy around "the economy, stupid."

;

;The Biden administration has worked to lower costs by releasing stores of the country's strategic petroleum stockpile, pushing down health insurance premiums, negotiating the cost of common prescription drugs, and trying to end monopolies in meat processing and ;battling "junk" fees; paid by consumers.

;

;They've also touted hundreds of billions of dollars in infrastructure investments during Biden's term as increasing the capacity of the US economy going forward by easing supply chain constraints. Critics say that spending and the associated deficits may actually be fueling higher prices.

;

;A Biden adviser said the White House understands that the economy and inflation are a critical issue, and the campaign has a big media push planned on "Bidenomics." The adviser added that many voters see threats to democracy and their rights as vital, too, and the strong performance of Democrats in the midterm elections last year shows that.

;

;Analysts, economists and the media closely track the main inflation gauge, the US Consumer Price Index, for its monthly window on how much prices have risen from a month or a year ago.

;

;In the 12 months through August, the ;CPI accelerated 3.7%;, a sharp drop from its peak of 9.1% in June of 2022.

;

;But that's not what voters care about. Even as the pace of price hikes recedes, the sticker shock from previous increases remains. Just because inflation falls, in other words, it doesn't mean prices fall back to where they were - only that they are growing less quickly.

;

;Anyone in a grocery store is less likely to appreciate that meat, poultry, fish and eggs are slightly less expensive now than they were at the start of the year - inflation among those goods was negative for several months - than to grimace at the fact that those core sources of protein still cost about 24% more than they did on the eve of the pandemic in early 2020.

;

;In a mid-1990s survey, Yale University economics professor and Nobel Prize winner Robert Shiller found that inflation associated with no less than "a tone of moral indignation."

;

;"People tell of businesses trying too hard to pursue profits, the Fed behaving stupidly, people trying to live above their means, or politicians trying too hard to get reelected," Shiller wrote.

;

;In ;another telling survey; in the summer of 2022, management consulting firm McKinsey & Company found that the onset of inflation had promptly doubled the percentage of respondents seen in previous polls who felt pessimistic about the economy - dwarfing the numbers seen even at the depths of a pandemic that would go on to kill 1.1 million people in the US and throw the economy into chaos.

;

;"Now that inflation has accelerated to its highest rate in four decades, the mood has turned darker," the McKinsey study said.

;

;The headline to the American Psychological Association's ;"Stress in America 2022"; report from October of last year was headlined "Concerned for the future, beset by inflation."

;

;How could paying more at the grocery store or the gas station compare with a mass catastrophe like the pandemic?

;

;In the latter case, a multi-trillion-dollar government safety net had given people a bridge through the initial spike in unemployment and provided a buffer for them to stay away from jobs until they regarded the workplace as safe.

;

;There is no similar buffer from higher prices, a stretched family budget, or an eroding retirement. Inflation is universal and efforts to combat it with things like price controls or subsidies typically don't work.

;

;Biden ;promised; this month to get gasoline prices down again, a rash vow for any president given the limited impact an administration has on prices at the pump.

;

;The question is how long the inflation scar will last from here, whether the pace of price increases continues to moderate, and whether, as the Fed seems to anticipate, the rest of the economy remains on track.

;

;If it goes according to the central bank's current expectations, there may even be interest rate cuts thrown into the mix next year, letting Biden test the premise of whether running on a strong economy in an environment of easing credit works as well as running against an economic downturn, financial tightening, and rising prices.

;

;There's some indication a turn in public sentiment could be in the making even before that happens. The US Census Bureau's most recent Household Pulse survey, for the two weeks ending Sept. 4, showed that while 80% of respondents were still "somewhat" or "very" concerned about future inflation, the number had fallen from earlier peaks in every state.

;

;As Powell noted last week, there is a schism between what people say in surveys and how they behave.

;

;When asked a question, they are sour.

;

;When left alone, they go shopping.

;

;"It's a very hot labor market ... You're starting to see real wages are now positive by most metrics ... Overall, households are in good shape," Powell said in his Sept. 20 press conference after the end of the latest Fed policy meeting. "Surveys are a different thing. Surveys are showing dissatisfaction. I think a lot of it is people hate inflation. Hate it. And that causes people to say the economy's terrible. At the same time they're spending money. Their behavior is not exactly what you'd expect from the survey."

;

;Related Galleries:

;;
;;A woman shops for groceries at El Progreso Market in the Mount Pleasant neighborhood of Washington, DC, US, August 19, 2022. REUTERS/Sarah Silbiger/File Photo;
;;
;;US President Joe Biden meets with Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen to talk about the economy in the Oval Office at the White House in Washington, DC, US, May 31, 2022. REUTERS/Leah Millis/File Photo;
;;

; Tue, 26 Sep 2023 18:25:04 +0800 Turkey will back Sweden“s NATO bid if U.S. keeps promise on F-16 sale -Erdoganhttps://reuters.com/article/nato-nordics-turkey-usa/turkey-will-back-swedens-nato-bid-if-u-s-keeps-promise-on-f-16-sale-erdogan-idUSKBN30W0LP
;;2023-09-26T10:10:09Z;
;;
;;An F-16 combat jet of the US Airforce is prepared for practice flights ahead of the Air Defender Exercise 2023 at the military airport of Jagel, northern Germany, on June 9, 2023. AXEL HEIMKEN/Pool via REUTERS/ File Photo;
;

;Turkey's parliament will keep its promise to ratify Sweden's NATO bid if US President Joe Biden's administration paves the way for F-16 jet sales to Ankara, President Tayyip Erdogan said on Tuesday, according to Turkish media.

;

;Speaking to reporters on his flight back from Azerbaijan's exclave of Nakhchivan, Erdogan said that Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan and US Secretary of State Antony Blinken discussed Sweden's NATO membership bid last week in New York.

;

;The US administration is linking F-16 fighter jet sales to Turkey with Ankara's ratification of Sweden's bid, Erdogan said.

;

;"If they (the US) keep their promises, our parliament will keep its own promise as well. Turkish parliament will have the final say on Sweden's NATO membership," he said.

; Tue, 26 Sep 2023 18:25:04 +0800 Analysis: Cisco“s $28 billion Splunk deal may ignite software deal frenzyhttps://reuters.com/article/usa-software-deals-analysis/analysis-ciscos-28-billion-splunk-deal-may-ignite-software-deal-frenzy-idUSKBN30W0LV
;;2023-09-26T10:12:19Z;
;;
;;People pass by Cisco stand on the Web Summit, Europe's largest technology conference, in Lisbon, Portugal, November 3, 2021. REUTERS/Pedro Nunes;
;

;Cisco Systems' ;(CSCO.O); $28 billion deal for Splunk ;(SPLK.O); is likely to prompt other technology giants to splash out on similar acquisitions of software vendors with predictable subscription revenue, investment bankers and analysts say.

;

;Splunk, a cybersecurity and data analytics firm, was in the process of shifting its business model from licensing its software to charging for subscriptions when it announced ;an agreement; last week to sell itself to Cisco, making it the third-largest software acquisition of all time.

;

;Cisco CEO Chuck Robbins, who has been expanding his company's services offerings to compensate for its moribund telecommunications equipment business, told analysts that the $4 billion in annual recurring revenue that Splunk would bring from its subscriptions was a key driver behind the deal.

;

;This underscores how Splunk's subscription revenue-focused peers, such as Elastic NV ;(3E1.F);, Datadog ;(DDOG.O);, Crowdstrike Holdings ;(CRWD.O); and Dynatrace ;(DT.N);, are potential acquisition targets for technology conglomerates such as Microsoft ;(MSFT.O);, Adobe ;(ADBE.O); and Oracle ;(ORCL.N);, which are grappling with corporate customers seeking to cut spending, the bankers and analysts said.

;

;Microsoft, Adobe and Oracle did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

;

;The improving outlook for software mergers and acquisitions is a welcome boost for dealmakers, which have seen activity in the technology sector drop 61% year-to-date in the first 8 months of 2023 to $231.5 billion, according to LSEG data.

;

;Dealmaking in the software sector has been dominated by private equity firms over the past year facing little competition from technology giants. New Relic ;(NEWR.N);, a Splunk competitor, ;agreed in July; to be sold to private equity firms Francisco Partners and TPG Inc ;(TPG.O); for $6.5 billion.

;

;David Chen, co-head of global technology investment banking at Morgan Stanley ;(MS.N);, predicts that a rally in the Nasdaq 100 index this year and market fears of an economic recession receding will embolden technology companies to follow Cisco's example and spend on big acquisitions.

;

;"I think the buyers' outlook on their own business has really improved from four months ago, and that gives confidence to pull the trigger on transformational transactions," Chen said in an interview.

;

;Jefferies analysts wrote in a note the Federal Reserve putting the brakes on interest rate hikes has given acquirers more certainty around their funding costs, helping dealmaking.

;

;Even before Cisco's deal, there were some signs that technology giants had started to eye acquisitions of software firms this year, albeit at a smaller scale. IBM ;(IBM.N);, for example, ;agreed in June; to buy technology spend-management platform Apptio for $4.6 billion.

;

;Splunk's stock performance made it receptive to a takeover. While its shares had risen 39% in 2023 prior to the deal's announcement, they were still down 44% from their October 2020 high, when the COVID-19 pandemic forced companies to spend more on information technology because most of their employees were working from home. Many of Splunk's peers have had similar stock performance.

;

;Software stocks are cheap by historical standards, making them attractive acquisition targets. The average software stock trades at 5.8 times projected 12-month revenue, 28% below its 8-year historical average when excluding the impact of COVID-19, which temporarily buoyed valuations in the sector, according to the Jefferies analysts.

;

;Cisco's deal valued Splunk at 7 times projected 12-month revenue, according to Jefferies. They and other analysts said the price Cisco was paying was reasonable.

;

;"We note that the typical security company with 20% growth trades at about 7 times (sales)," BTIG analysts wrote in a note last week.

;

;Private software companies may also be more receptive to takeovers. Keith Skirbe, managing director in Houlihan Lokey's ;(HLI.N); technology investment banking group, said that some companies that raised money at high valuations during the 2021 fundraising cycle prefer to be sold rather than be forced to raise money from their investors again at a lower valuation.

;

;"A tidal wave of software M&A (is) on the horizon," Wedbush analysts wrote in a note last week.

; Tue, 26 Sep 2023 18:25:04 +0800
